definition: Zhao Qi (-201 BC), early Han commentator on Mencius 孟子[Meng4 zi3]
to surpass (old)
surname Zhao/one of the seven states during the Warring States Period (476-220 BC)/the Former Zhao 前趙 (304-329) and Later Zhao 後趙 (319-350), states of the Sixteen Kingdoms
variant of 歧[qi2]
surname Qi/also used in place names
Zheng Xuan (127-200), late Han scholar
Kong Yingda (574-648), Confucian scholar
Huangfu Song (-195), later Han general and warlord
Kong Rong (153-208), poet of the Three Kingdoms period
Ban Gu (32-92), Eastern Han dynasty historian, wrote the Dynastic History of Western Han 漢書|汉书
Sima Tan (-110 BC), Han dynasty scholar and historian, and father of 司馬遷|司马迁[Si1 ma3 Qian1]
Xun Yu (163-212), brilliant strategist, advisor of Cao Cao in Three Kingdoms
Dong Zhongshu (179-104 BC), philosopher influential in establishing Confucianism as the established system of values of former Han dynasty
Cheng Yu (141-220), advisor to General Cao Cao 曹操 during the Three Kingdoms era
Wang Chong (27-97), rationalist and critical philosopher
Wang Su (c. 195-256), classical scholar of Cao Wei dynasty, believed to have forged several classical texts
Grand Servant in imperial China, one of the Nine Ministers 九卿[jiu3 qing1]
Zhu Jun (-195), politician and general at the end of later Han

History of Eastern Han (later Han), third of the 24 dynastic histories 二十四史[Er4 shi2 si4 Shi3], composed by Fan Ye 范曄|范晔[Fan4 Ye4] in 445 during Song of the Southern Dynasties 南朝宋[Nan2 chao2 Song4], 120 scrolls
Fang Xuanling (579-648), Tang dynasty historian, compiler of History of Jin dynasty 晉書|晋书
the lord of Lu (who declined to employ Confucius)
